Notes of a general household life-cycle problem with linear budget

Tianhao Zhao (GitHub: Clpr) Jan 2019

Background

Assumptions

Denotation

  1. lowercase letters, such as c,k,lc,k,lc,k,l, are used to denote the variables with economic meanings
  2. capital letters, such as A,B,CA,B,CA,B,C, are used to denote general algebrae. These algebrae are usually input by users
  3. specifically, sss denotes time/moment/period; ccc denotes consumption; lll denotes labor (not leisure!); kkk denotes wealth/capital; bbb denotes bequests (if applicable)

Demography

  1. One life-cycle problem is solved for only a (group of homogeneous) agent(s). If there are multiple agent groups (e.g. income groups), each group's life-cycle problem needs to be separately solved.
  2. Finite life expectancy, where the maximum limit of life is S≥2S\geq2S≥2 (years).
  3. Determined retirement age 1≤Sr<S1 \leq S_r < S1≤Sr​<S, i.e. an agent works for SrS_rSr​ years.
  4. s=1,…,S+1s = 1,\dots,S+1s=1,…,S+1 is used to denote the moment of the beginning of a year; e.g. when we talk about "year ttt", it means we are talking about a period from the moment s=t,s=1,…,Ss=t,s=1,\dots,Ss=t,s=1,…,S to moment s=t+1s=t+1s=t+1. However, we define some special moments:
    1. An agent is born at the beginning of the 1st year; the moment of birth is marked as s=1s=1s=1.
    2. An agent begins to work when born at the moment s=1s=1s=1, then retires at the end of the last working year SrS_rSr​; the moment of retirement is marked as s=Sr+1s=S_r+1s=Sr​+1. It means that the agent is still working in year SrS_rSr​. He/she becomes retired at moment Sr+1S_r+1Sr​+1 (the beginning of age-year Sr+1S_r+1Sr​+1!), then he/she begins to receive pension benefits in year Sr+1S_r+1Sr​+1.
    3. An agent dies at the end of the very last year, where the moment is marked as s=S+1s=S+1s=S+1. It means this agent spends his last year, makes all deals (e.g. consumptions) then dies at the end of year SSS.
  5. Deaths, no matter accidental deaths before s=S+1s=S+1s=S+1 or the fatal natural death at moment s=S+1s=S+1s=S+1, always happen at the end of years, i.e. agents always finish other activities such as consumption in their dead years before the moment of death.
  6. No agent dies at moment s=1s=1s=1 (no die-young case considered)

Utility

  1. Cross-sectional utility function u(c,l)u(c,l)u(c,l) is defined as the utility obtained from one year's consumption and labor supply. u(c,l)u(c,l)u(c,l) is consumption-labor separable, i.e. u(cs,ls)=u1(cs)+u2(ls)u(c_s,l_s) = u_1(c_s) + u_2(l_s)u(cs​,ls​)=u1​(cs​)+u2​(ls​)
  2. Agents try to maximize UUU, the summation of the present values of every year's cross-sectional utilities. The optimization can be denoted with a Bellman equation.
  3. Agents use utility discounting factors βs≠0,1≤s≤S\beta_s \neq 0,1\leq s\leq Sβs​̸​=0,1≤s≤S to discount the cross-sectional utility u(cs,ls)u(c_s,l_s)u(cs​,ls​) in year sss to moment s−1s-1s−1.

Consumption, Work, Retirement

  1. Agents only care his/her private interests; no children's interests considered.
  2. Perfect forward-looking.
  3. Agents possess capital ks,s=1,…,S+1k_s,s=1,\dots,S+1ks​,s=1,…,S+1, where ksk_sks​ is a moment amount. ksk_sks​ denotes the capital at the beginning of year sss.
  4. Agent decide every year's consumption cs,s=1,…,Sc_s,s=1,\dots,Scs​,s=1,…,S & labor 0≤ls≤lˉs,s=1,…,Sr0\leq l_s\leq \bar{l}_s,s=1,\dots,S_r0≤ls​≤lˉs​,s=1,…,Sr​, where lˉs\bar{l}_slˉs​ is time endowment; by default, lˉs≡1\bar{l}_s \equiv 1lˉs​≡1 for each sss. And, be careful, both csc_scs​ & lsl_sls​ is a period amount, i.e. they indicates the consumption/labor during the period from moment s=ss=ss=s to moment s=s+1s=s+1s=s+1.
  5. For the convenient of computing, ls≡0l_s\equiv 0ls​≡0 for s=Sr,…,Ss=S_r,\dots,Ss=Sr​,…,S.
  6. No final bequest left, i.e. agents always try to spend all their capital before natural fatal death at s=S+1s=S+1s=S+1.
  7. No capital when born.
  8. Capital is never less than zero (ks≥0k_s\geq 0ks​≥0)

Budget Constraint

  1. Agents' consumption & labor supply are constrained by linear inter-temporal budget constraints:
    1. Before retirement: Asks+1=Bsks+Dsls−Escs+Fs,1≤s≤SrA_s k_{s+1} = B_s k_{s} + D_s l_s - E_s c_s + F_s, 1\leq s \leq S_rAs​ks+1​=Bs​ks​+Ds​ls​−Es​cs​+Fs​,1≤s≤Sr​
    2. After retirement: Asks+1=Bsks−Escs+Fs,Sr<s≤SA_s k_{s+1} = B_s k_{s} - E_s c_s + F_s, S_r< s\leq SAs​ks+1​=Bs​ks​−Es​cs​+Fs​,Sr​<s≤S
    3. where As>0A_s>0As​>0 is a multiplier; Bs>0B_s>0Bs​>0 is a multiplier; Ds,Es≠0D_s, E_s \neq 0Ds​,Es​̸​=0 are multipliers; and Fs∈RF_s \in \bm{R}Fs​∈R is the extra cash/capital flows not related to possessed capital, labor or consumption.
  2. According to our assumptions in previous sections, we have some boundary conditions:
    1. Ask2=D1l1−E1c1+F1A_s k_{2} = D_1 l_1 - E_1 c_1 + F_1As​k2​=D1​l1​−E1​c1​+F1​, which is equivalent to k1≡0k_1 \equiv 0k1​≡0.
    2. 0=BSkS+DSlS−EScS+FS0 = B_S k_{S} + D_S l_S - E_S c_S + F_S0=BS​kS​+DS​lS​−ES​cS​+FS​, which is equivalent to kS+1≡0k_{S+1} \equiv 0kS+1​≡0.

Mathematics: Problem Statements (DP)

This life-cycle problem can be written as a standard DP problem:

(1)v(s)=max⁡cs,ls[u(cs,ls)+βsv(s+1)],s=1,…,Ss.t.{Asks+1=Bsks+Dsls−Escs+Fs,1≤s≤Sls=0,s=Sr+1,…,Sk1=kS+1=0v(S+1)=0−ks≤0,s=1,…,S+1−cs≤0,s=1,…,Sls≤lsˉ,s=1,…,Sr−ls≤0,s=1,…,Srv(s) = \max_{c_s,l_s} [ u(c_s,l_s) + \beta_s v(s+1) ], s=1,\dots,S \\ s.t. \begin{cases} A_s k_{s+1} = B_s k_{s} + D_s l_s - E_s c_s + F_s, 1\leq s \leq S \\ l_s = 0, s=S_r+1,\dots,S \\ k_1 = k_{S+1} = 0 \\ v(S+1) = 0 \\ -k_s \leq 0, s= 1,\dots,S+1 \\ -c_s \leq 0, s = 1,\dots,S \\ l_s \leq \bar{l_s}, s=1,\dots,S_r \\ -l_s \leq 0, s=1,\dots,S_r \\ \end{cases} \tag{1}v(s)=cs​,ls​max​[u(cs​,ls​)+βs​v(s+1)],s=1,…,Ss.t.⎩⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎧​As​ks+1​=Bs​ks​+Ds​ls​−Es​cs​+Fs​,1≤s≤Sls​=0,s=Sr​+1,…,Sk1​=kS+1​=0v(S+1)=0−ks​≤0,s=1,…,S+1−cs​≤0,s=1,…,Sls​≤ls​ˉ​,s=1,…,Sr​−ls​≤0,s=1,…,Sr​​(1)

where As>0,Bs>0,Ds≠0,Es≠0,Fs∈R,βs≥0A_s>0,B_s>0,D_s\neq 0,E_s\neq 0,F_s\in\bm{R},\beta_s\geq0As​>0,Bs​>0,Ds​̸​=0,Es​̸​=0,Fs​∈R,βs​≥0 are exogeneous parameters which should be manually input/set by users/economists. Meanwhile, users need to explicitly define the structure of the cross-sectional utility function u(c,l)u(c,l)u(c,l) according to our assumptions.

Based on Eq (1), users may use standard DP algorithms to solve this problem. However, solving this DP problem for many times (esp. in a large model system) may bring un-acceptable time cost. Therefore, I introduce a half-analytical approximated solution instead. This half-analytical algorithm uses Lagrange functions without the inequalities of endowment constraints (cs,ls,ksc_s,l_s,k_scs​,ls​,ks​ etc.). It solves such a partial-constrained (only equality constraints!) problem, then uses a simple root-searching algorithm to find the consumption & labor & capital paths which meet those inequality endowment constraints). Of course, quite different from DP which does not require the structure of u(∙)u(\bullet)u(∙), the proposed half-analytical algorithm uses the analytical FOCs of u(∙)u(\bullet)u(∙) to accelerate computations. Therefore, the proposed algorithm requires the explicit definition of u(∙)u(\bullet)u(∙), which leads to so many strong assumptions above. In this document, I will state one of the most simplest case: consumption-leisure separable u(∙)u(\bullet)u(∙).

A Recursive Series

Before discussing the proposed half-analytical algorithm, let's look at the recurrence formula of a series:

(2)xt+1=atxt+bt,t≥1x_{t+1} = a_{t} x_{t} + b_{t}, t\geq1 \tag{2}xt+1​=at​xt​+bt​,t≥1(2)

where {xt∣t≥1}\{x_{t}| t\geq1\}{xt​∣t≥1} is the real-number series, at>0a_{t}>0at​>0 and bt∈Rb_t\in\bm{R}bt​∈R are exogeneous parameters, and x1x_{1}x1​ is a known constant. Readers may feel familiar with this series because it is an abstract form of our inter-temporal budget constraint. However, this series cannot be simply summarized because ata_{t}at​ is variant with ttt. Now, our task is clear: how to use k1k_{1}k1​, the known constant, to denote any ksk_{s}ks​ for s>1s>1s>1?

Let's use mathematical induction:

Proof 1: xs(x1),s>1x_{s}(x_{1}), s>1xs​(x1​),s>1

  1. Substitute x2=a1x1+b1x_{2} = a_1 x_1 +b_1x2​=a1​x1​+b1​ to x3=a2x2+b2x{3} = a_2 x_2 + b_2x3=a2​x2​+b2​, then get: x3=a2(a1x1+b1)+b2=a2a1x1+a2b1+b2x_3 = a_2(a_1 x_1 + b_1) + b_2 = a_2 a_1 x_1 + a_2 b_1 + b_2x3​=a2​(a1​x1​+b1​)+b2​=a2​a1​x1​+a2​b1​+b2​;
  2. Substitute x3x_3x3​ to x4x_4x4​, then get: x4=x1∏i=34ai+(a4a3a2b1+a4a3b2+a4b3+b4)x_4 = x_1 \prod^4_{i=3} a_i + ( a_4 a_3 a_2 b_1 + a_4 a_3 b_2 + a_4 b_3 + b_4 )x4​=x1​∏i=34​ai​+(a4​a3​a2​b1​+a4​a3​b2​+a4​b3​+b4​);
  3. Define: ∏i=nmai≡1\prod^m_{i=n} a_i \equiv 1∏i=nm​ai​≡1 for ∀n>m\forall n>m∀n>m;
  4. Therefore, guess: xs+1=x1∏i=1sai+∑j=1s(bj∏i=j+1sai),s≥1x_{s+1} = x_1 \prod^s_{i=1} a_i + \sum^s_{j=1}( b_j \prod^s_{i=j+1} a_i ), s\geq 1xs+1​=x1​∏i=1s​ai​+∑j=1s​(bj​∏i=j+1s​ai​),s≥1;
  5. If our guess is true, we have: xs+2=x1∏i=1s+1ai+∑j=1s+1(bj∏i=j+1s+1ai),s≥1x_{s+2} = x_1 \prod^{s+1}_{i=1} a_i + \sum^{s+1}_{j=1}( b_j \prod^{s+1}_{i=j+1} a_i ), s\geq 1xs+2​=x1​∏i=1s+1​ai​+∑j=1s+1​(bj​∏i=j+1s+1​ai​),s≥1;
  6. Substitute xs+1x_{s+1}xs+1​ to xs+2=as+1xs+1+bs+1x_{s+2} = a_{s+1}x_{s+1} + b_{s+1}xs+2​=as+1​xs+1​+bs+1​, then get: xs+2=x1∏i=1s+1ai+∑j=1s+1(bj∏i=j+1s+1ai),s≥1x_{s+2} = x_1 \prod^{s+1}_{i=1} a_i + \sum^{s+1}_{j=1}( b_j \prod^{s+1}_{i=j+1} a_i ), s\geq 1xs+2​=x1​∏i=1s+1​ai​+∑j=1s+1​(bj​∏i=j+1s+1​ai​),s≥1;
  7. Therefore, our guess is true.

So far, we have proved:

(3)xs+1=x1∏i=1sai+∑j=1s(bj∏i=j+1sai),s≥1x_{s+1} = x_1 \prod^s_{i=1} a_i + \sum^s_{j=1}( b_j \prod^s_{i=j+1} a_i ), s\geq 1 \tag{3}xs+1​=x1​i=1∏s​ai​+j=1∑s​(bj​i=j+1∏s​ai​),s≥1(3)

Now, let's go back to our inter-temporal budget constraint:

(4)Asks+1=Bsks+Dsls−Escs+Fs,1≤s≤SA_s k_{s+1} = B_s k_{s} + D_s l_s - E_s c_s + F_s, 1\leq s \leq S \tag{4}As​ks+1​=Bs​ks​+Ds​ls​−Es​cs​+Fs​,1≤s≤S(4)

Because we have assumed As>0,Bs>0A_s>0,B_s>0As​>0,Bs​>0, this recursive formula of budget constraint can be written as:

(5)ks+1=BsAsks+(DsAsls−EsAscs+FsAs),1≤s≤Sk_{s+1} = \frac{B_s}{A_s} k_{s} + ( \frac{D_s}{A_s} l_s - \frac{E_s}{A_s} c_s + \frac{F_s}{A_s} ) , 1\leq s \leq S \tag{5}ks+1​=As​Bs​​ks​+(As​Ds​​ls​−As​Es​​cs​+As​Fs​​),1≤s≤S(5)

Eq (5) looks familiar? Right! Denote xs=ksx_{s} = k_sxs​=ks​, ai=BiAia_i = \frac{B_i}{A_i}ai​=Ai​Bi​​ and bj=DjAjlj−EjAjcj+FjAjb_j = \frac{D_j}{A_j} l_j - \frac{E_j}{A_j} c_j + \frac{F_j}{A_j}bj​=Aj​Dj​​lj​−Aj​Ej​​cj​+Aj​Fj​​, then substitute them to Eq (3), we have:

(6)ks+1=k1∏i=1sBiAi+∑j=1s[(DjAjlj−EjAjcj+FjAj)∏i=j+1sBiAi],s≥1k_{s+1} = k_1 \prod^s_{i=1} \frac{B_i}{A_i} + \sum^s_{j=1}[ (\frac{D_j}{A_j} l_j - \frac{E_j}{A_j} c_j + \frac{F_j}{A_j}) \prod^s_{i=j+1} \frac{B_i}{A_i} ], s\geq 1 \tag{6}ks+1​=k1​i=1∏s​Ai​Bi​​+j=1∑s​[(Aj​Dj​​lj​−Aj​Ej​​cj​+Aj​Fj​​)i=j+1∏s​Ai​Bi​​],s≥1(6)

or equivalently:

(7)ks+1=k1∏i=1sBiAi+∑j=1s(DjAjlj∏i=j+1sBiAi)−∑j=1s(EjAjcj∏i=j+1sBiAi)+∑j=1s(FjAj∏i=j+1sBiAi),s≥1k_{s+1} = k_1 \prod^s_{i=1} \frac{B_i}{A_i} + \sum^s_{j=1} (\frac{D_j}{A_j} l_j \prod^s_{i=j+1}\frac{B_i}{A_i}) - \sum^s_{j=1}(\frac{E_j}{A_j} c_j\prod^s_{i=j+1}\frac{B_i}{A_i}) + \sum^s_{j=1}(\frac{F_j}{A_j} \prod^s_{i=j+1} \frac{B_i}{A_i}) , s\geq 1 \tag{7}ks+1​=k1​i=1∏s​Ai​Bi​​+j=1∑s​(Aj​Dj​​lj​i=j+1∏s​Ai​Bi​​)−j=1∑s​(Aj​Ej​​cj​i=j+1∏s​Ai​Bi​​)+j=1∑s​(Aj​Fj​​i=j+1∏s​Ai​Bi​​),s≥1(7)

Now, let s=Ss=Ss=S, then kS+1k_{S+1}kS+1​ becomes bequests, the capital when agents die. According to our assumptions, kS+1=0k_{S+1}=0kS+1​=0, thus, define:

(8)G(cs,ls∣s=1,…,S)=k1∏i=1SBiAi+∑j=1S[(DjAjlj−EjAjcj+FjAj)∏i=j+1SBiAi],s≥1G(c_s,l_s|s=1,\dots,S) = k_1 \prod^S_{i=1} \frac{B_i}{A_i} + \sum^S_{j=1}[ (\frac{D_j}{A_j} l_j - \frac{E_j}{A_j} c_j + \frac{F_j}{A_j}) \prod^S_{i=j+1} \frac{B_i}{A_i} ], s\geq 1 \tag{8}G(cs​,ls​∣s=1,…,S)=k1​i=1∏S​Ai​Bi​​+j=1∑S​[(Aj​Dj​​lj​−Aj​Ej​​cj​+Aj​Fj​​)i=j+1∏S​Ai​Bi​​],s≥1(8)

Therefore, all inter-temporal budget constraints have been compressed to a single equation:

(9.A)G(cs,ls∣s=1,…,S)=0G(c_s,l_s|s=1,\dots,S) = 0 \tag{9.A}G(cs​,ls​∣s=1,…,S)=0(9.A)

For the convenience of the following inductions, we write the partial differentiations of csc_scs​ and lsl_sls​:

(9.B){∂G∂cs=−EsAs∏i=s+1SBiAi∂G∂ls=DsAs∏i=s+1SBiAi\begin{cases} \frac{\partial G}{\partial c_s} = - \frac{E_s}{A_s} \prod^S_{i=s+1}\frac{B_i}{A_i} \\ \frac{\partial G}{\partial l_s} = \frac{D_s}{A_s} \prod^S_{i=s+1}\frac{B_i}{A_i} \end{cases} \tag{9.B}{∂cs​∂G​=−As​Es​​∏i=s+1S​Ai​Bi​​∂ls​∂G​=As​Ds​​∏i=s+1S​Ai​Bi​​​(9.B)

Mathematics: Problem Statements (Lagrange)

The proposed half-analytical algorithm requires the following partial-constrained optimization problem denoted as an standard maximization problem:

(10)max⁡cs,s=1,…,S;ls,s=1,…,SrU=∑s=1Sβsu(cs,ls)s.t. G(cs,ls∣s=1,…,S)=0\max_{c_s,s=1,\dots,S; l_s,s=1,\dots,S_r} U = \sum^S_{s=1} \beta_s u(c_s,l_s) \\ \text{s.t. }G(c_s,l_s|s=1,\dots,S) = 0 \tag{10}cs​,s=1,…,S;ls​,s=1,…,Sr​max​U=s=1∑S​βs​u(cs​,ls​)s.t. G(cs​,ls​∣s=1,…,S)=0(10)

In Eq (10), we temporarily neglect all endowment constraints because they are inequalities, and use standard Lagrange multiplier to solve Eq (10). The Lagrange function is:

(11)max⁡cs,s=1,…,S;ls,s=1,…,SrL=U(cs,ls∣s=1,…,S)−λG(cs,ls∣s=1,…,S)\max_{c_s,s=1,\dots,S; l_s,s=1,\dots,S_r} L = U(c_s,l_s|s=1,\dots,S) - \lambda G(c_s,l_s|s=1,\dots,S) \tag{11}cs​,s=1,…,S;ls​,s=1,…,Sr​max​L=U(cs​,ls​∣s=1,…,S)−λG(cs​,ls​∣s=1,…,S)(11)

Now, we are going to solve this problem with FOCs & Euler equation.

FOCs and Euler Equation

To solve Eq (11), we need the first-order conditions (FOCs) of Eq (11). We have assumed that the cross-sectional utility function u(c,l)u(c,l)u(c,l) is explicitly defined and it is a consumption-labor separable u(c,l)=u1(c)+u2(l)u(c,l) = u_1(c) + u_2(l)u(c,l)=u1​(c)+u2​(l). Therefore, we write the FOCs of Eq(11):

(12){∂U∂cs=βs∂u∂cs−λ∂G∂cs=0,s=1,…,S∂U∂ls=βs∂u∂ls−λ∂G∂ls=0,s=1,…,Sr∂U∂λ=G=0\begin{cases} \frac{\partial U}{\partial c_s} = \beta_s \frac{\partial u}{\partial c_s} - \lambda \frac{\partial G}{\partial c_s} = 0, s = 1,\dots,S \\ \frac{\partial U}{\partial l_s} = \beta_s \frac{\partial u}{\partial l_s} - \lambda \frac{\partial G}{\partial l_s} = 0, s = 1,\dots,S_r \\ \frac{\partial U}{\partial \lambda} = G = 0 \end{cases} \tag{12}⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​∂cs​∂U​=βs​∂cs​∂u​−λ∂cs​∂G​=0,s=1,…,S∂ls​∂U​=βs​∂ls​∂u​−λ∂ls​∂G​=0,s=1,…,Sr​∂λ∂U​=G=0​(12)

Because λ>0\lambda>0λ>0, combining ∂U∂cs\frac{\partial U}{\partial c_s}∂cs​∂U​ and ∂U∂cs+1\frac{\partial U}{\partial c_{s+1}}∂cs+1​∂U​, we get our Euler equation:

(13)∂u/∂cs∂u/∂cs+1=βs+1βs∂G/∂cs∂G/∂cs+1,s=1,…,S−1\frac{ \partial u / \partial c_s }{ \partial u / \partial c_{s+1} } = \frac{\beta_{s+1}}{\beta_{s}} \frac{ \partial G / \partial c_s }{ \partial G / \partial c_{s+1} } , s = 1,\dots,S-1 \tag{13}∂u/∂cs+1​∂u/∂cs​​=βs​βs+1​​∂G/∂cs+1​∂G/∂cs​​,s=1,…,S−1(13)

The Euler equation, when ∂u/∂cs\partial u/\partial c_s∂u/∂cs​ is explicitly defined, can be equivalently denoted as a recursive formula of csc_scs​:

(14)cs=ε(s∣c1)c_s = \varepsilon(s|c_1) \tag{14}cs​=ε(s∣c1​)(14)

which we will use to compress the optimization about many csc_scs​ to a new one only about c1c_1c1​. Meanwhile, combining ∂U∂ls\frac{\partial U}{\partial l_s}∂ls​∂U​ and ∂U∂cs\frac{\partial U}{\partial c_{s}}∂cs​∂U​, we can get the optimal conversion formula from lsl_sls​ to csc_scs​ without endowment constraints:

(15)∂u/∂cs∂u/∂ls=∂G/∂cs∂G/∂ls,s=1,…,Sr\frac{ \partial u / \partial c_s }{ \partial u / \partial l_{s} } = \frac{ \partial G / \partial c_s }{ \partial G / \partial l_{s} } , s = 1,\dots,S_r \tag{15}∂u/∂ls​∂u/∂cs​​=∂G/∂ls​∂G/∂cs​​,s=1,…,Sr​(15)

which is equivalent to the following conversion function:

(16)ls=γ~(cs)=γ~(ε(s∣c1))=γ(s∣c1)l_s = \tilde{\gamma}(c_s) = \tilde{\gamma}(\varepsilon(s|c_1)) = \gamma(s|c_1) \tag{16}ls​=γ~​(cs​)=γ~​(ε(s∣c1​))=γ(s∣c1​)(16)

So far, we have used the information of the first two conditions of Eq(12). Now, we substitute Eq(14) and Eq(16) to G=0G = 0G=0 to solve the optimal c1∗c^*_1c1∗​ where no endowment constraints are considered:

(17)G(cs∗,ls∗∣s=1,…,S)=G(c1∗)=0G(c^*_s,l^*_s|s=1,\dots,S) = G(c^*_1) = 0 \tag{17}G(cs∗​,ls∗​∣s=1,…,S)=G(c1∗​)=0(17)

Adjustment on lsl_sls​

Eq (17) has answered the optimal paths of cs∗c^*_scs∗​ and ls∗l^*_sls∗​ under the conditions without endowment constraints. However, endowment constraints, i.e. cs≥0c_s\geq 0cs​≥0 and 0≤ls≤lˉs0\leq l_s \leq \bar{l}_s0≤ls​≤lˉs​, are essential which cs∗c^*_scs∗​ and ls∗l^*_sls∗​ cannot always meet. Therefore, we need to adjust cs∗c^*_scs∗​ and ls∗l^*_sls∗​ to make them meet these endowment constraints.

Algorithm: adjust ls∗l^*_sls∗​ and cs∗c^*_scs∗​

1.Assumptions:

  1. The dynamics of consumptions (Euler equation) are retained, no matter what the value of c1∗c^*_1c1∗​ and/or what the values of ls∗l^*_sls∗​;
  2. However, the conversion formula ls∗=γ~(cs∗)l^*_s = \tilde{\gamma}(c^*_s)ls∗​=γ~​(cs∗​) is now not retained because we adjusted ls∗l^*_sls∗​;
  3. Budget constraint G=0G=0G=0 must be satisfied.
  1. Algorithm:
  1. Let l~s∗=[[ls∗,lˉs]−,0]+\tilde{l}^*_s = [[l^*_s,\bar{l}_s]^-,0]^+l~s∗​=[[ls∗​,lˉs​]−,0]+ be the bounded/adjusted labor supplies, where [a,b]+[a,b]^+[a,b]+ denotes the larger one of a,ba,ba,b, and [a,b]−[a,b]^-[a,b]− denotes the smaller one of a,ba,ba,b;
  2. Solve the equation G(c~s∣l~s,s=1,...,S)=G(c~1∣ε(⋅),l~s,s=1,...,S)=0G(\tilde{c}_s|\tilde{l}_s,s=1,...,S) = G(\tilde{c}_1|\varepsilon(\cdot),\tilde{l}_s,s=1,...,S) = 0G(c~s​∣l~s​,s=1,...,S)=G(c~1​∣ε(⋅),l~s​,s=1,...,S)=0 with numerical root-searching algorithms (e.g. bisection search).

Our problem

Specific to our household problem in this paper, we use a logarithm cross-sectional utility function:

(18)u(c,l∣lˉ>0,q∈(0,1))=11−γ−1[[(1−q)c+ϵ]1−γ−1+α[lˉ−l+ϵ]1−γ−1]u(c,l|\bar{l}>0,q\in(0,1)) = \frac{1}{1-\gamma^{-1}} [ [(1-q)c + \epsilon]^{1-\gamma^{-1}} + \alpha [\bar{l} - l + \epsilon ]^{1-\gamma^{-1}} ] \tag{18}u(c,l∣lˉ>0,q∈(0,1))=1−γ−11​[[(1−q)c+ϵ]1−γ−1+α[lˉ−l+ϵ]1−γ−1](18)

where ϵ\epsilonϵ is an infinitesimal which is the tolerance of computer's float point arithmetics. It is used to avoid the domain errors raised by exact zero. Therefore, we have:

(19){∂u∂cs=(1−qs)1−γ−1cs−γ−1,1≤s≤S∂u∂cs=−α(lˉs−ls)−γ−1,1≤s≤Sr\begin{cases} \frac{\partial u}{\partial c_s} = (1-q_s)^{1-\gamma^{-1}} c_s^{-\gamma^{-1}}, 1\leq s\leq S \\ \frac{\partial u}{\partial c_s} = -\alpha (\bar{l}_s - l_s) ^ {-\gamma^{-1}}, 1\leq s\leq S_r \end{cases} \tag{19}{∂cs​∂u​=(1−qs​)1−γ−1cs−γ−1​,1≤s≤S∂cs​∂u​=−α(lˉs​−ls​)−γ−1,1≤s≤Sr​​(19)

where we neglect ϵ\epsilonϵ in analytical solutions but add it when programming.

Then, we re-write our Euler equation in Eq (13):

{[1−qs1−qs+1]1−γ−1[cs+1cs]γ−1=βs+1βsEsEs+1As+1As∏s+1SBiAi∏s+2SBiAi,s=1,…,S−1(1−qs)1−γ−1−α[lˉs−lscs]γ−1=−EsDs,s=1,…,Sr\begin{cases} [\frac{1-q_s}{1-q_{s+1}}]^{1-\gamma^{-1}} [\frac{c_{s+1}}{c_{s}}]^{\gamma^{-1}} = \frac{\beta_{s+1}}{\beta_{s}} \frac{E_{s}}{E_{s+1}} \frac{A_{s+1}}{A_{s}} \frac{\prod^S_{s+1} \frac{B_i}{A_i}}{\prod^S_{s+2} \frac{B_i}{A_i}}, s= 1,\dots,S-1 \\ \frac{(1-q_s)^{1-\gamma^{-1}}}{-\alpha} [\frac{\bar{l}_s-l_s}{c_s} ]^{\gamma^{-1}} = - \frac{E_s}{D_s}, s= 1,\dots,S_r \end{cases} ⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​[1−qs+1​1−qs​​]1−γ−1[cs​cs+1​​]γ−1=βs​βs+1​​Es+1​Es​​As​As+1​​∏s+2S​Ai​Bi​​∏s+1S​Ai​Bi​​​,s=1,…,S−1−α(1−qs​)1−γ−1​[cs​lˉs​−ls​​]γ−1=−Ds​Es​​,s=1,…,Sr​​

Naturally, we ask for: γ≠0\gamma\neq 0γ̸​=0, q∈(0,1)q\in(0,1)q∈(0,1), α≠0\alpha\neq 0α̸​=0, β≠0\beta\neq 0β̸​=0, D,E≠0D,E \neq 0D,E̸​=0, A,B>0A,B > 0A,B>0. After simplification, we have Eq (20):

(20){cs+1cs=[βs+1βsEsEs+1Bs+1As]γ[1−qs1−qs+1]1−γ,s=1,…,S−1lˉs−lscs=[αEsDs]γ(1−qs)1−γ,s=1,…,Sr\begin{cases} \frac{c_{s+1}}{c_{s}} = [ \frac{\beta_{s+1}}{\beta_{s}} \frac{E_{s}}{E_{s+1}} \frac{B_{s+1}}{A_{s}} ]^{\gamma} [\frac{1-q_{s}}{1-q_{s+1}}]^{1-\gamma} , s= 1,\dots,S-1 \\ \frac{\bar{l}_s-l_s}{c_s} = [\alpha \frac{E_s}{D_s}]^{\gamma} (1-q_s)^{1-\gamma} , s= 1,\dots,S_r \end{cases} \tag{20}{cs​cs+1​​=[βs​βs+1​​Es+1​Es​​As​Bs+1​​]γ[1−qs+1​1−qs​​]1−γ,s=1,…,S−1cs​lˉs​−ls​​=[αDs​Es​​]γ(1−qs​)1−γ,s=1,…,Sr​​(20)

Because γ>0\gamma>0γ>0 and it is usually less than 1, we specially requires Es/Ds>0E_s/D_s > 0Es​/Ds​>0.

Then, we define some new abbreviations:

(21){Ms,s+1=βs+1βsEsEs+1Bs+1As,s=1,…,S−1Ns,s+1=1−qs1−qs+1,s=1,…,S−1Ps=αEsDs,s=1,…,SrQs=1−qs,s=1,…,Sr\begin{cases} M_{s,s+1} = \frac{\beta_{s+1}}{\beta_{s}} \frac{E_{s}}{E_{s+1}} \frac{B_{s+1}}{A_{s}}, s= 1,\dots,S-1 \\ N_{s,s+1} = \frac{1-q_{s}}{1-q_{s+1}}, s=1,\dots,S-1 \\ P_{s} = \alpha \frac{E_s}{D_s}, s=1,\dots,S_r \\ Q_{s} = 1-q_s, s=1,\dots,S_r \end{cases} \tag{21}⎩⎪⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎪⎧​Ms,s+1​=βs​βs+1​​Es+1​Es​​As​Bs+1​​,s=1,…,S−1Ns,s+1​=1−qs+1​1−qs​​,s=1,…,S−1Ps​=αDs​Es​​,s=1,…,Sr​Qs​=1−qs​,s=1,…,Sr​​(21)

where according to our assumptions, we have: Ms,s+1,Ns,s+1,Ps,Qs>0M_{s,s+1},N_{s,s+1},P_{s},Q_{s} > 0Ms,s+1​,Ns,s+1​,Ps​,Qs​>0. Therefore, we can rewrite our Euler equation and the conversion equation between consumption and labor in Cobb-Douglas form:

(22){cs+1cs=Ms,s+1γNs,s+11−γ,s=1,…,S−1lˉs−lscs=PsγQs1−γ,s=1,…,Sr\begin{cases} \frac{c_{s+1}}{c_{s}} = M_{s,s+1}^{\gamma} N_{s,s+1}^{1-\gamma} , s= 1,\dots,S-1 \\ \frac{\bar{l}_s-l_s}{c_s} = P_{s}^{\gamma} Q_{s}^{1-\gamma} , s= 1,\dots,S_r \end{cases} \tag{22}{cs​cs+1​​=Ms,s+1γ​Ns,s+11−γ​,s=1,…,S−1cs​lˉs​−ls​​=Psγ​Qs1−γ​,s=1,…,Sr​​(22)

(23){cs=ε^(s,c1∣s=1,…,S)=c1(∏i=1s−1Mi,i+1)γ(∏i=1s−1Ni,i+1)1−γls=γ^(s,c1∣s=1,…,Sr)=lˉs−cs(∏i=1sPi)γ(∏i=1sQi)1−γ=lˉs−c1(∏i=1s−1Mi,i+1)γ(∏i=1s−1Ni,i+1)1−γ(∏i=1sPi)γ(∏i=1sQi)1−γ\begin{cases} c_{s} = \hat{\varepsilon}(s,c_1|s=1,\dots,S) = c_1 (\prod^{s-1}_{i=1} M_{i,i+1})^{\gamma} (\prod^{s-1}_{i=1} N_{i,i+1})^{1-\gamma} \\ l_{s} = \hat{\gamma}(s,c_1|s=1,\dots,S_r) = \bar{l}_s - c_s (\prod^{s}_{i=1} P_{i})^{\gamma} (\prod^{s}_{i=1} Q_{i})^{1-\gamma} = \bar{l}_s - c_1 (\prod^{s-1}_{i=1} M_{i,i+1})^{\gamma} (\prod^{s-1}_{i=1} N_{i,i+1})^{1-\gamma} (\prod^{s}_{i=1} P_{i})^{\gamma} (\prod^{s}_{i=1} Q_{i})^{1-\gamma} \\ \end{cases} \tag{23}{cs​=ε^(s,c1​∣s=1,…,S)=c1​(∏i=1s−1​Mi,i+1​)γ(∏i=1s−1​Ni,i+1​)1−γls​=γ^​(s,c1​∣s=1,…,Sr​)=lˉs​−cs​(∏i=1s​Pi​)γ(∏i=1s​Qi​)1−γ=lˉs​−c1​(∏i=1s−1​Mi,i+1​)γ(∏i=1s−1​Ni,i+1​)1−γ(∏i=1s​Pi​)γ(∏i=1s​Qi​)1−γ​(23)

Of course, here we still have the relationship ∏nmx≡1\prod^m_n x \equiv 1∏nm​x≡1 for ∀n>m\forall n>m∀n>m.

So far, we have got the all conditions to solve c1c_1c1​. Then, we substitute Eq (23) into our linear budget constraint G=0G = 0G=0 in Eq (9.A) to solve c1c_1c1​:

Summary of Our Problem

Up to now, we have obtained the half-analytical solutions of our problem. In this section, we summarize this problem.

a. Cross-sectional Utility Function

u(c,l∣lˉ>0,q∈(0,1))=11−γ−1[[(1−q)c+ϵ]1−γ−1+α[lˉ−l+ϵ]1−γ−1]u(c,l|\bar{l}>0,q\in(0,1)) = \frac{1}{1-\gamma^{-1}} [ [(1-q)c + \epsilon]^{1-\gamma^{-1}} + \alpha [\bar{l} - l + \epsilon ]^{1-\gamma^{-1}} ] u(c,l∣lˉ>0,q∈(0,1))=1−γ−11​[[(1−q)c+ϵ]1−γ−1+α[lˉ−l+ϵ]1−γ−1]

b. Problem Statement

Summary of Our Problem (Only Retired Years)

In practice, we not only need to solve the problems with both working and retired years, but also need to solve the problems with only retired years. This happens when we compute the transition path in years t=1,…,St=1,\dots,St=1,…,S. In these years, those who are alive in year 0 (initial steady state), according to shocks in year 1, will re-solve the optimal consumption-leisure-capital paths in their left years. For those who have retired in year 0, naturally, they optimize their utilities with a budget constraint without labor supply, i.e. they just decide how to consume their savings but won't worry about whether to work. Therefore, the solutions of these only-retired problems changed, but still similar to our original problems. We restate the only-retired problem in this section.

a. Cross-sectional Utility Function

u(c,l≡0∣lˉ>0,q∈(0,1))=11−γ−1[[(1−q)c+ϵ]01−γ−1+α[lˉ−l+ϵ]1−γ−1]u(c,l\equiv 0|\bar{l}>0,q\in(0,1)) = \frac{1}{1-\gamma^{-1}} [ [(1-q)c + \epsilon]^0{1-\gamma^{-1}} + \alpha [\bar{l} - l + \epsilon ]^{1-\gamma^{-1}} ] u(c,l≡0∣lˉ>0,q∈(0,1))=1−γ−11​[[(1−q)c+ϵ]01−γ−1+α[lˉ−l+ϵ]1−γ−1]

b. Problem Statement

max⁡cs,s=1,…,S;ls,s=1,…,SrU=∑s=1Sβsu(cs,0)s.t. G(cs,0∣s=1,…,S)=0\max_{c_s,s=1,\dots,S; l_s,s=1,\dots,S_r} U = \sum^S_{s=1} \beta_s u(c_s,0) \\ \text{s.t. }G(c_s,0|s=1,\dots,S) = 0 cs​,s=1,…,S;ls​,s=1,…,Sr​max​U=s=1∑S​βs​u(cs​,0)s.t. G(cs​,0∣s=1,…,S)=0

where SSS now is defined as the number of maximum left years that the agents can live, and:

{G(cs,0∣s=1,…,S)=k1∏i=1SBiAi+∑j=1S[(−EjAjcj+FjAj)∏i=j+1SBiAi]∏nmx≜1,∀n>m\begin{cases} G(c_s,0|s=1,\dots,S) = k_1 \prod^S_{i=1} \frac{B_i}{A_i} + \sum^S_{j=1}[ ( - \frac{E_j}{A_j} c_j + \frac{F_j}{A_j}) \prod^S_{i=j+1} \frac{B_i}{A_i} ] \\ \prod^m_n x \triangleq 1, \forall n > m \end{cases} {G(cs​,0∣s=1,…,S)=k1​∏i=1S​Ai​Bi​​+∑j=1S​[(−Aj​Ej​​cj​+Aj​Fj​​)∏i=j+1S​Ai​Bi​​]∏nm​x≜1,∀n>m​

where k1k_1k1​ now is defined as agents' capital held in year 0 (steady state), or equivalently, at the beginning of the year when agents make life-cycle decisions.

In fact, we can see this problem is equivalent to a standard problem with given zero labor supplies. Therefore, the solution of this problem is just a variant of Eq(29):

(29)c~1∗=H+∑j=1SKj−∑j=1SJjXj\tilde{c}^*_1 = \frac{ H + \sum^S_{j=1} K_j }{ - \sum^S_{j=1} J_j X_j } \tag{29}c~1∗​=−∑j=1S​Jj​Xj​H+∑j=1S​Kj​​(29)

Functions in Computing

The type of "Custom" means this function should be made according to scenarios. The type of "General" means this function is a general one as long as the cross-sectional utility function u(c,l)u(c,l)u(c,l) is the same one as we use in our problem.

Type Function Name Inheritance & Reference Notes
Custom lev0Abbr(::Dict) No inheritance Uses original data to create a Dict of those Level 0 abbreviations; also performs data validations
General lev1Abbr(::Dict) The results of lev0Abbr() Creates a Dict of those Level 1 abbreviations; also performs data validations
General lev2Abbr(::Dict) The results of lev1Abbr() Creates a Dict of those Level 2 abbreviations; also performs data validations
General getks(::Int,::Real,::Vector,::Vector,::Dict) The results of lev0Abbr() Gets the capital ks,s=1,…,S+1k_s,s=1,\dots,S+1ks​,s=1,…,S+1 in a specific year
General G(::Vector,::Vector,::Dict) The results of lev0Abbr() The budget constraint; used to exam if solutions are right
General HHSolve() all others Solves the household life-cycle problem, considering both working & retired phases
General lev0Abbr_Retired() No inheritance Create Level 0 abbreviations for the only-retired problems
General lev1Abbr_Retired() The results of lev0Abbr_Retired()
General lev2abbr_Retired() The results of lev1Abbr_Retired()
General getks_Retired() The results of lev0Abbr_Retired()
General G_Retired() The results of lev0Abbr_Retired()
